subject: Re: [junit] Re: how to use ExceptionTestCase ?
msgSnippet: ... My comment is harsh, so be prepared for it: this attitude makes me sick to my stomach. It is *not* all right for the application to crash when something
messageBody:
>So said Paul Zabelin on 2003-05-28 --------------------
>--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Lucas <lucas.bline@l...> wrote:
>> import junit.extensions.ExceptionTestCase;
>>
>> public class Exception1Test extends ExceptionTestCase {
>>
>> public Exception1Test(String arg0, Class ex) {
>> super(arg0, ex);
>> }
>>
>> public void testThis() throws Exception {
>> assertTrue(true);
>> // no exception by now, but should work anyway
>> }
>> }
>>
>>
>> the above code gives the following error:
>>
>> junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: Class
>exception.Exception1Test has no
>> public constructor TestCase(String name)
>>
>
>I have been using ExceptionTestCase successfully for several
>projects. The advantage of having special TestCase class is:

>1. Separates Exceptional behaviour test code. Throwing exception can
>be slower compared to normal workflow. Failure on exception class can
>be classified as exceptable for code shipment, while normal test
>failure has to be a showstoper.

My comment is harsh, so be prepared for it: this attitude makes me sick to my stomach.

It is *not* all right for the application to crash when something simple goes wrong. There will always be very difficult problems that we cannot solve in time to ship the product, but failure to handle an exception must not automatically be considered less important than correctly handling the "happy paths".

>2. Fails if wrong exception class thrown or nothing was thrown.

That's not always enough: does the exception object thrown contain adequate information to describe the exception?

Exception tests in particular are more of a design tool than a testing tool: writing good exception tests leads to better exception classes, which leads to higher serviceability and maintainability, which saves lots of money down the line trying to track down difficult-to-diagnose problems at the client site. People who do not practise TDD probably think exception tests are a waste of time and they wouldn't be far off. Exception tests show their value most in the context of TDD.

>3. Typical exception cause is wrong method parameters or
>preconditions. So it takes a lot of tests to be written to create
>different exceptional conditions.

Wrong method parameters or failed preconditions indicate a bug elsewhere, and not a bug in the method trying to receive those parameters. It usually indicates that the caller is not adequately tested. "Defensive programming" is truly paranoid programming and should be avoided.
